sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving solids
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the following reaction: 

Fe2O3(s) + 3CO(g) → 2Fe(s) + 3CO2(g) 

given the following standard enthalpy of formation values: 

ΔHf°[Fe2O3(s)] = -824.2 kJ/mol 
ΔHf°[CO(g)] = -110.5 kJ/mol 
ΔHf°[Fe(s)] = 0 kJ/mol 
ΔHf°[CO2(g)] = -393.5 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔH°(reaction) = Σ ΔHf°(products) - Σ ΔHf°(reactants)

For the products, we have 2 moles of Fe(s) and 3 moles of CO2(g):
Σ ΔHf°(products) = (2 × 0 kJ/mol) + (3 × -393.5 kJ/mol) = -1180.5 kJ/mol

For the reactants, we have 1 mole of Fe2O3(s) and 3 moles of CO(g):
Σ ΔHf°(reactants) = (-824.2 kJ/mol) + (3 × -110.5 kJ/mol) = -1155.7 kJ/mol

Now, we can calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction:
ΔH°(reaction) = -1180.5 kJ/mol - (-1155.7 kJ/mol) = -24.8 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change for the reaction is -24.8 kJ/mol.
